1.5.10  Hot Work Procedures (Appendix L of the RMP)

COY has established hot work procedures to monitor and control spark- or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions within the regulated process areas.  COY will utilize hot work procedures to comply with California OSHA requirements.  Personnel who perform hot work within the chlorine process areas are required to be familiar with COY¿s hot work procedures.  Additionally, the responsible managers/supervisors periodically review COY¿s hot work procedures to be sure they are adequate.  Training in the use of the hot work procedures is included in COY¿s safe work practices orientation.

1.5.11  Contractor Safety (Appendix M of the RMP)

COY established a program to help ensure that contractor activities at the WWTP facility is performed in a safe manner.  COY explains to the contract supervisors the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, safe work practices, and proper emergency response procedures.  COY personnel inspect contractor work activities when working in and around the WWTP chlorine process areas to help ensure that safe work practices are followed.  COY only utilizes contractors that are familiar with their processes and facilities, and have the knowledge and training to perform their duties effectively and safely.

1.0  Executive Summary

City of Yreka (COY) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, COY has established a system to help ensure safe operations of its regulated processes.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMProgram) that is designed to manage the risks at COY¿s regulated facilities.  Additionally, COY's Risk Management Plan (RMP) complies with all requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program; the California OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standards; and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requirements.

COY¿s RMP consists of these three major elements:
1.  A hazard assessment to aid in understanding the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases, and an assessment of accidents that have occurred during the past five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMProgram Rule.
2.  A prevention program to assist in maintaining and safely operating any processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance.
3.  An emergency response program to help respond to an accidental release of regulated substances from the covered processes.

Information further describing these elements is provided in COY's RMP.

Although an RMP will assist COY in providing assurance that the Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of their overall safety program.  In fact, COY has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards against a release of a hazardous substance, and injuries and damage resulting from a release of a hazardous substance.  Additionally, COY has a Safety Director who initiates safety committee walkthroughs, and obtains outside contractors to assist with maintenance and safety related issues regarding their regulated processes.

COY has limited its use of hazardous

substances at its facilities, and has eliminated the storage of chlorine gas at one of their sites.  Before using a hazardous substance at COY's WWTP, less hazardous alternatives are considered.  When a hazardous substance is used, COY considers the potential for this substance to adversely affect their employees, the public, and the environment, and takes steps to prevent such effects.

COY works to prevent releases of hazardous substances that are stored and used at its WWTP.  COY's WWTP is very well maintained, and the facility and process equipment were designed, built, and are being operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  Industry and government standards were adhered to in the original design, construction, and operation of the facilities and its process equipment, and current regulations are adhered to in new designs, construction, and operations of the regulated processes.

COY limits damage from a release, if such a release should occur by training specific employees to respond to an accidental release.  In addition, COY works closely with the the COY Fire and Police Departments, and the Shasta Cascade Hazardous Materials Response Team (SCHMRT), to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimal, if a release from a regulated substance should occur.

The safety program at COY consists of a number of elements that conform to CalARP Program 3 requirements.  

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

COY is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous and regulated substances.  COY implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes at the WWTP; and programs to manage the risks at facilities that

store and use regulated substances.

In the event of an accidental release, COY, the Yreka Fire and Police Departments, and the SCHMRT will work to control and contain the spill or release in a manner that will be safe for the responders and the employees, and will help prevent injury to the public and minimize damage to the environment.  If an accidental release occurs, COY will revise Sections 5 and 6 of their RMP to include information about the accident and the related incident investigation, and provide it to EPA within six months.  Additionally, the expected date of completion of changes due to the accident investigation will be incorporated into the RMP and submitted to EPA within six months of the accident.

COY provides response training to specific personnel, designates an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the Yreka Fire and Police Departments, and the SCHMRT.  COY and the Fire Department have conducted emergency response training in February of 2005, and will be conducting another training session with COY's other emergency responders.  Additionally, specific COY employees will undergo trianing to be certified for using respirators and the proper PPE for responding to a release from the regulated substance.  Specific COY employees/responders are also members of the fire department. 

To effectively implement these policies, COY has established a management system headed by the Public Works Director (Emergency Response Coordinator) along with the Water and Wastewater Managers, which have oversight for COY's faciities, to oversee safety-related and emergency response activities.  These Managers all report to the City Manager.

1.2  COY¿s Regulated Substances Handled and Source Information

COY¿s WWTP facility serves the City of Yreka, and as part of the wastewater treatment process, chlorine gas is used and stored in sufficient quantities to be covered by the CalARP Program 3 requirements,

California OSHA Process Safety Management Standards, and U.S. EPA RMP requirements. COY's WWTP contains approximately 8,300 lbs of chlorine gas (2 one-ton cylinders on-line, 2 one-ton cylinders strapped on top of storage cradle, and (2) 150-lb cylinders strapped to supports, all within the chlorine process room a the WWTP.

1.3  Off-Site Consequence Analysis (Appendix A of the RMP)

An Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) was prepared to address worst-case and alternative scenarios for chlorine releases from COY¿s WWTP facility.  The completed off-site consequence analysis is presented in Appendix A for safety reasons and should not be released without prior approval from the City of Yreka.

1.4  Mitigation Measures

COY has implemented administrative controls and mitigation measures at its facilities in order to minimize the potential of an off-site release or, in the event of a release, the quantity of the release.

Administrative controls in effect at the COY facilities, which were considered to mitigate the severity of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios, include COY¿s policies and procedures for training of operators and maintenance personnel, procedures for control of the inventory of chlorine at the facility, and policies regarding quality level of replacement materials and components for the chlorine systems.  Active mitigation measures include timely response of properly trained and equipped personnel who will be following the established emergency response procedures;placement of the chlorine systems (including all cylinders stored) in a dedicated room within an enclosed building, which is fire rated;a SCADA computer system that alerts the operators of when there are system problems; chlorine leak detector sensors and interconnected audible/visual alarm systems for the chlorine process areas;automatic shut-down valves for the on-line chlorine cylinders;a overhead sprinkler system inside the chlorine process room;a secured and well-constructed f

acility and systems;engineered ventilation and warning systems at the WWTP process area;protection for cylinder valves and piping;cylinders secured in place;fusible plugs on the one-ton gas cylinders;placement of a wind sock at the facility; and an emergency generator that will provide power during an outage.

1.5  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Process Safety Information (Appendix B of the RMP)

COY maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operations of the WWTP regulated process.  These documents address the physical properties of hazardous substances handled at their facilities, operating parameters of the systems, and equipment operating procedures for the regulated process.  COY ensures that this process safety information is available to its employees and the outside emergency responders.

International Chemical Safety Cards are produced by the international safety community and are cosponsored by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH).  This resource is intended to provide health and safety information for workers potentially in contact with regulated substances.  The International Chemical Safety Cards for chlorine are provided in Appendix B. 

Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) document the physical properties of hazardous substances handled at COY, including chlorine gas (cylinders) used at the WWTP, WPS, and WFP facilities.  The MSDSs for chlorine gas is presented in Appendix B.  The information available on the MSDSs for each hazardous substance typically includes:

· toxicity information and permissible exposure limits
· physical data (e.g., boiling point, melting point, flash point)
· reactivity and corrosivity data
· thermal and chemical stability data
· hazards of mixing substances in the process

MSDSs for regulated substances handled at the WWTP are available at the office of the Water and Wastewater Managers, so that the operators have ready accessibility to this informatio

n.  In addition, MSDSs are provided to the outside emergency response teams for use in developing emergency response planning and procedures.

1.5.1  Process Hazard Analysis (Appendix C of the RMP)

A process hazard analysis (PHAs) was performed for the WWTP facility and its regulated process in March through August of 2005, to identify potential hazards and to produce recommendations that may promote safer operation of these systems and processes.  The PHA is updated at least every 5 years or when significant changes occur.  A team composed of personnel with engineering process operating experience, and a leader with process hazard analyses experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of each process.  PHA What-If Questions and a Hazard Review Checklist were used to perform the analysis (Appendix C).  Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to unit personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the processes are implemented.  The PHA team incorporated information from the site inspection into the responses on the PHA What-If Questions and the Hazard Review Checklist.  

1.5.2  Operating Procedures (Appendix D of the RMP)

COY operators and managers work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed.  The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to be taken during both normal operations and process upsets.

COY personnel develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.  The most current information is found in the Operations and Maintenance (O & M) Manuals located in the wastewater manager¿s office.  

The Appendices also include other relevant information:

·  WWTP site p

lans and off site consequence analysis are to be controlled, and are not for public use without prior approval (Appendix A of the RMP)
·  Block flow diagrams (Appendix D fo the RMP)
·  Chemical/electrical building plans with critical system shutoff locations 

When important information is not available from the design documents, it should be developed through special projects or, in the case of operating parameters, during the process hazards analyses.  Many of the operating parameters are included in the operating procedures to help with the safe operation of the process.  These documents are used to train employees, to perform process hazards analyses, and to help maintain the equipment.

1.5.3  Training (Appendix E of the RMP)

COY has permits to operate the WWTP facility and processes, and operators at the WWTP are state-certified for operating facilities with chlorine processes, so they can safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The training programs for the operators cover the properties of the substances and the hazards of those substances;orientation of the chlorine process and systems; health and safety training; and emergency respopnse training.  Specific operators are required to pass the state certification exam and complete a specified number of continuing education units related to the wastewater treatment plant operations on an ongoing basis.  In addition, safety meetings are held annually, at a minimum.  COY conducts training for WWTP operators covering the use of full-face supplied air respirators, personal protective equipment (PPE), chlorine safety, safe cylinder changing procedures, and understanding MSDS sheets.  Training is documented and kept on file at the WWTP and WTP Managers office.  In February of 2005, COY and the Fire Department conducted emergency response training.  Pioneer provided a safety inspection with recommendation, and a chlorine safety training CD in February and March of 2005.  In March of 2005, SHN conducted

a site walk and provided safety training recommendations.  

1.5.4  Mechanical Integrity (Appendix F of the RMP) 

COY has established a mechanical integrity program for the chlorine processes at their WWTP facility.  The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure that all vessels, piping, instrumentation, and other components essential to the containment of this material are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of an accidental release.  The elements of COY¿s mechanical integrity program for chlorine include:

· Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation, 
· Maintenance procedures, 
· Training of maintenance personnel, 
· Defined inspection and test procedures and frequencies, 
· Documentation of test and inspection results, and 
· A quality assurance program to help ensure that equipment is designed, fabricated, and installed properly.

1.5.5  Pre-startup Review (Appendix G of the RMP)

COY performs a Pre-Startup Safety Review of all new or modified process prior to the introduction of a regulated material, to ensure that the system will operate safely.  This review confirms:
· Construction is in accordance with specifications;
· Appropriate testing and inspections have been performed;
· Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate;
· Safety Review recommendations have been addressed and actions required for startup have been completed; and
· Operating procedures are in place and training of personnel has been completed.

1.5.6  Management of Change (Appendix H of the RMP)

COY¿s Management of Change (MoC) program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process, to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without implementing the full MoC progr

am.

All major changes to the regulated processes must be confirmed through the MoC program, in order to ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

1.5.7  Compliance Audit (Appendix I of the RMP)

A Compliance Audits (CA) was conducted for the WWTP and its regulated process in March through August of 2005, to determine whether the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations.  COY assembled an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the RMP Rule and in the processes, and this team evaluated whether the prevention program satisfies the requirement of the RMP Rule, and whether it is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the processes.                                                                                                                                                                            
1.5.8  Incident Investigation (Appendix J of the RMP)

COY will investigate all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment, so that similar accidents can be prevented.  COY provides training to employees in order to identify and report any incident requiring investigation.  An investigation team will be assembled, and the investigation will be initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation will be documented, recommendations will be presented and reviewed, and appropriate process enhancements will be implemented.  No incidents were reported for more than 5-years; therefore, no incident investigation were conducted. 

1.5.9  Employee Participation Program (Appendix K of the RMP)

COY has developed an employee participation program to help ensure that the safety concerns of its process workers are properly addressed.  COY encourages active

ocess control companies and engineers to design, maintain, and service COY¿s chlorine control systems and related equipment.  On February 8, 2005, Pioneer conducted a site visit, and on March 4, 2005, they provided COY with a list of safety recommendations, which are in the process of being implemented.  Pioneer also assists COY in implementation of its preventative maintenance program, and as required, they will make repairs and/or install new process equipment, or replace existing equipment is found to be defective or worn.  

COY¿s WWTP has chlorine leak detectors located near the floor in the chlorine process rooms, which will signal those that monitor the SCADA computer system, and also any on-site personnel. If these alarms are not acknowledged within a specific time, the on-call operators are called at their contact number outside of work and notified.  The on-call operators are within a quick reponse time of the WWTP facility.  As an additional precaution, there are on-site automatic audible and visible alarms (red lights outside the entry door of the WWTP process area, which will alert employees and visitors to evacuate the premises).  

COY has an emergency shut down system at the WWTP for the on-line chlorine cylinders.  Automatic shut-off valves are located on the downstream side of the flexible pigtail connection at each cylinder that will shut down the systems upon sensing low pressure in the piping downstream from this valve.  If a release occurs downstream of the vacuum switchover valve (vacuum loss), the valve will close and only the quantity in the piping will be released.  Air-supplied respirators are located outside the chlorine process areas at the facility.

At the WWTP, four one-ton chlorine cylinders are strapped onto their saddle supports, which are bolted to the slab (per design drawings), and two 150-lb cylinders are strapped to supports, all within the chlorine process area.  Additionally, a ventilation system can be energized from outsid

e the process area, and also a red warning light will come on to warn personnel before entering the room, if a leak has been detected.   

The piping systems and supports for the WWTP regulated processes appear to be up to the required standards, and pipe supports are securely mounted to solid structures.  The cylinders and gas piping systems are located within areas that will secure them from large objects, which could fall and damage the cylinders or supply system.  Equipment inspections are regularly conducted and recorded by operational staff.  Flexible pigtail connections are used and the process piping is adequately supported.  The chlorine use and storage room has a chlorine leak detector sensor with a backup notification system.

When transporting a one-ton cylinder, the valve cover remains in place, the cylinders are loaded and unloaded utilizing the proper equipment, and the cylinder are set into a saddle support and strapped in place.  Only trained employees complete the cylinder transfer process, and adhere to strict guidelines when completing this process.                                                                        
                                                                                                                                                                                       1.7  Five-Year Accident History (Section 5.0 of the RMP)

COY has reported no accidents, personal injuries, or property damage in the last five years, with regard to a release of chlorine gas.  If an incident occurs, an investigation team will conduct an investigation following the incident investigation protocol.  The team will suggest improvements to the process and, if appropriate, improvements will be made.  Additionally, a report will be completed and will be kept on file.

1.8  Emergency Response Program (Section 8.0 of the RMP)

COY has established a written emergency response program to ensure a safe response to an accidental release of chlori

ne gas.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for: 

·  Fires 
·  Medical Emergencies
·  Earthquakes, Disasters
·  Emergency Spills

As per safety recommendations by Pioneer and SHN, COY is in the process of updating its emergency response training and conducting OSHA hazardous materials training for its process personnel and responders.  Pioneer and SHN have conducted site visits and safety reviews with COY, and Pioneer provided COY with a training CD to help meet the OSHA requirements.  In 2005, COY personnel and the COY Fire Department conducted emergency response training, and also conducted a site walk through.  Additional training is being implemented since the SCHMRT (one of the few certified and trained responders) have a response time that may be 2 hours or more.  During the planned emergency response training all affected COY personnel, COY¿s Fire and Police Departments, and the SCHMRT will be provided with the emergency response plan and procedures.

1.9  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

COY constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated processes, through both the incident investigation program and the practice of encouraging safety suggestions for improvement from the workers.  COY¿s preventative maintenance program also helps ensure that the equipment and processes are operating in a safe and efficient manner.

The WWTP has personnel on-site 24 hours per day; however, they need updated health and safety training and emergency repsonse training, which is in the process of being implemented in 2005.
